entry.title: Protocols, Not Platforms : A Technological Approach to Free Speech : Hacker News
entry.summary: - The market will rush to build the best client for the protocol. Facebook, Google, maybe an outsider will come up with the best client that has all the features and added goodies (magic emojis, special video effects, something new etc).

entry.title: Free Speech Futures
entry.summary: The Knight Institute’s second essay series asked contributing authors to envision new approaches to First Amendment doctrine and to online content moderation. The eight essays in the series consider the future of free speech along two dimensions.

entry.title: Protocols, Not Platforms: A Technological Approach to Free Speech
entry.summary: After a decade or so of the general sentiment being in favor of the internet and social media as a way to enable more speech and improve the marketplace of ideas, in the last few years the view has shifted dramatically—now it seems that almost no one is happy.

entry.title: America's Missile That Uses Sword Blades Instead of Explosives Has Struck Again
entry.summary: remotecool 29 minutes ago This is a good thing. Less casualties than what happens with explosive warheads.

entry.title: How Art Can Be Good
entry.summary: I grew up believing that taste is just a matter of personal preference. Each person has things they like, but no one's preferences are any better than anyone else's. There is no such thing as good taste.

entry.title: Tom Coates on Twitter
entry.summary: Here’s my theory - the food writer @britishfood sends Spuce Eats a traditional British recipe. They decide to make it and take photos of it for the article. But they don’t know what mincemeat is, resulting in this unholy horror: https://www.thespruceeats.

entry.title: Gustav Soderstrom: Spotify
entry.summary: Gustav Soderstrom is the Chief Research & Development Officer at Spotify, leading Product, Design, Data, Technology & Engineering teams. This conversation is part of the Artificial Intelligence podcast. If you would like to get more information about this podcast go to https://lexfridman.

entry.title: The Mistakes I Made; Reflections on Nine Years Running DoubleDutch
entry.summary: It’s been about 8 weeks now since I have transitioned out of Cvent, the company that acquired DoubleDutch in June. I’ve had some time to sleep, to camp, to read scifi (hit me up for recommendations), to ride bikes and play hoops, and to spend amazing quality time with my wife and daughter.

entry.title: Life as a drone operator: 'Ever step on ants and never give it another thought?'
entry.summary: In a secluded room at an airbase in Nevada, young men hold the power of life and death over people thousands of miles away. Former servicemen tell their story

entry.title: Ask HN: Why GraphQL APIs but no Datalog APIs?
entry.summary: Facebook currently holds one of the largest levers in frontend development — React. If they say the officially recommended way to do X with React is Y, you can be sure that Y will get at least moderate traction.

entry.title: Why Your Website Needs a “Discovered Content” Section
entry.summary: One of the advantages of social content sharing is that if I like what you write then there’s a good chance I’ll like what you like as well.

entry.title: Machine Learning Will Revolutionize Content Discovery
entry.summary: There are going to be millions of surprising applications of Machine Learning in coming years and decades, but I believe I’ve found one of the biggest ones. Content Discovery.

entry.title: We need a major redesign of life
entry.summary: Laura L. Carstensen, a professor of psychology, is the director of the Stanford Center on Longevity. It’s time to get serious about a major redesign of life.

entry.title: How to Make Remote a Success
entry.summary: A couple of weeks ago, I attended the P9 Founder Summit in Malta organized by Point Nine Capital. One of the workshops was about remote work. Soon after, I led a webinar for the #p9family and I thought I would share our experience at Bearer thus far.

entry.title: Tao Te Ching : Chapter 17 : Translation by Stephen Mitchell
entry.summary: When the Master governs, the people are hardly aware that he exists. Next best is a leader who is loved. Next, one who is feared. The worst is one who is despised. If you don't trust the people, you make them untrustworthy.

entry.title: The US Army has an *exceptionally* well-crafted field manual on leadership. No f... : Hacker News
entry.summary: Being a DOD publication, it's in the public domain: https://usacac.army.mil/sites/default/files/misc/doctrine/CD... You don’t define how the subordinate should carry out the task – if they are competent and you trust them, they should be able to figure this out themselves.
